channel.title: Posts on Sports Data Blog
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Sports Data Blog

item.title: What's in a Kevin Willard Team
item.description: Maryland hired Kevin Willard, former Seton Hall coach, to the Terrapins men’s basketball program earlier this year. Willard joins the program after leading the Pirates for more than a decade. Through this analysis, we’ll identify what defines a Kevin Willard team and discuss what that might mean for Maryland. Let’s start by loading libraries and data. library(tidyverse) library(ggplot2) library(ggbeeswarm) library(gt) set.seed(1234) cbb <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/logs1222.csv") To begin, we’ll create a ton of average metrics by season and team.

item.title: Are College Teams Passing More on First Down?
item.description: In this analysis, we’ll explore whether college teams are passing more on first down. We’ll begin by loading in college football data and then we’ll narrow it to first down plays. We’ll analyze passing plays, calculate a percentage and then we’ll visualize in search of insights. Let’s begin by loading libraries. library(tidyverse) library(cfbfastR) library(ggalt) Let’s load the data, too. Here’s college football data from 2014 to 2022. tictoc::tic() pbp <- data.

item.title: NFL RedZone EPA Reverse Engineering
item.description: In this blog post, I’m going to confirm statistics from a FiveThirtyEight analysis and do a little bit of my own analysis of EPAs in the Red Zone from Week 3 to Week 8. I’ll start with the libraries. library(nflreadr) library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.2 ── ## ✔ ggplot2 3.3.6 ✔ purrr 0.3.4 ## ✔ tibble 3.1.8 ✔ dplyr 1.0.10 ## ✔ tidyr 1.2.1 ✔ stringr 1.

item.title: Volleybll Aces Beeswarm
item.description: Maryland Volleyball setter Sydney Dowler leads the team in aces per match, earning nearly two per match, according to an anlaysis of NCAA data. Fellow setter Erin Engel lags behind the metric. Middle blocker Laila Ricks, meanwhile, earns more aces per match than many of the best in the NCAA who play the same position. The data spans NCAA women’s volleyball players who have played at least 20 matches and have recorded some of the top numbers in aces per set.

item.title: Maryland Football YPP
item.description: Maryland football’s offense is more powerful than it was a decade ago, according to an analysis of years of NCAA data. The 2022-23 Maryland Football team is thriving in offensive yards per play, but isn’t as defensively powerful as past squads have been. So far this year, this season’s team has the highest win percentage compared to past seasons. The 2011-2012 squad only collected a few wins and is among the worst teams the football program has seen in the past ten years.

item.title: Recruiting Ratings and Wins
item.description: Let’s take a look at the relationship between ratings and recruiting in college football. I want to find out whether a team with a good recruiting class will translate to a lot of wins. Let’s start by loading the libraries. library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.2 ── ## ✔ ggplot2 3.3.6 ✔ purrr 0.3.4 ## ✔ tibble 3.1.8 ✔ dplyr 1.0.10 ## ✔ tidyr 1.2.1 ✔ stringr 1.

item.title: College Football First Plays
item.description: Indiana Quartberback Connor Bazelak threw an interception on the first offensive play of the game against Maryland on Saturday. That’s not something we see everyday. But let’s take a closer look to learn just how rare it is. Let’s load in some libraries. library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.2 ── ## ✔ ggplot2 3.3.6 ✔ purrr 0.3.4 ## ✔ tibble 3.1.8 ✔ dplyr 1.0.10 ## ✔ tidyr 1.

item.title: Volleyball Waffle Chart
item.description: #The task at hand: #To begin, I’m going to load in libraries. library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.2 ── ## ✔ ggplot2 3.3.6 ✔ purrr 0.3.4 ## ✔ tibble 3.1.8 ✔ dplyr 1.0.10 ## ✔ tidyr 1.2.1 ✔ stringr 1.4.1 ## ✔ readr 2.1.2 ✔ forcats 0.5.2 ## ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ## ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## ✖ dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() Let’s read the data.

item.title: Big Ten Football Average Plays
item.description: #The task at hand: Now that we’ve setup our Blogdown sites, I want you to use the chapterLinks to an external site./tutorial on Bar Charts to create a bar chart showing the average number of offensive plays for each Big Ten football team from the 2021-22 season (here’s the data you’ll need: https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs21.csvLinks to an external site.). To do this, you’ll need to follow the instructions from the Blogdown book chapter about creating a new post, and I want a mixture of words and code - essentially, narrate your code - and then provide a few sentences describing the data in the chart and what you think is the biggest lesson or takeaway from it.

item.title: First post
item.description: This is indeed my first post :wave:

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description: This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc. There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown.
